citations.narrative:
The barrier fence in front of an enclosure housing two Nanday parakeets and one yellow-headed Amazon parrot is only
23" from the front of the enclosure. The public can come into direct contact with the animals inside because the public
barrier fence is so close to the enclosure and cannot prevent this.
Public barriers are important to protect both animals and people; people or animals can be injured by unauthorized direct
contact and animals can become ill if they eat food or objects presented to them by people. The licensee must ensure that
barriers between the general viewing public and the animals are of a sufficient distance, height and integrity so as to
assure the safety of animals and the public.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the licensee is currently providing enrichment to the birds at the facility, there are no specific provisions listed in
a plan for the environmental enhancement of birds related to social grouping, special considerations, restraint and
exemptions.
The facility must further develop, document and follow a more complete, species appropriate plan for environmental
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending
veterinarian and, at a minimum, must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations,
restraint, and exemptions to the plan.
TO BE COMPLETED BY 10/13/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
The barrier fence in front of an enclosure housing two Nanday parakeets and one yellow-headed Amazon parrot is only 
23" from the front of the enclosure. The public can come into direct contact with the animals inside because the public 
barrier fence is so close to the enclosure and cannot prevent this. 
Public barriers are important to protect both animals and people; people or animals can be injured by unauthorized direct 
contact and animals can become ill if they eat food or objects presented to them by people. The licensee must ensure that 
barriers between the general viewing public and the animals are of a sufficient distance, height and integrity so as to 
assure the safety of animals and the public. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the licensee is currently providing enrichment to the birds at the facility, there are no specific provisions listed in 
a plan for the environmental enhancement of birds related to social grouping, special considerations, restraint and 
exemptions. 
The facility must further develop, document and follow a more complete, species appropriate plan for environmental 
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending 
veterinarian and, at a minimum, must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, 
restraint, and exemptions to the plan. 
TO BE COMPLETED BY 10/13/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
